course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Statistics for Financial Risk Management
course.description: This course provides an introduction to financial risk management. Topics include how to measure market risks, statistical properties of returns and volatility, volatility modeling, Value at Risk (VaR), Risk Metrics, historical simulation, assessing VaR methods and stress testing. Theories will be illustrated by practical examples in financial markets.
course.prerequisites: ISOM 3540 (Note: Students who have sufficient background in probability but without pre-requisite may enroll in the course upon approval by the instructor)

reviews.author: HKUST-er
reviews.title: Difficult but useful course
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1 – Introduction
Topic 2 – Stylized Facts of Financial Returns
Topic 3 – Measures of Market Risk
Topic 4 – Volatility Estimation and Modeling
Topic 5 – Simulation and Tail Behavior
Topic 6 – Dynamic Covariance and Correlation Modeling
Topic 7 – Simulation and Risk Term Structure
Topic 8 – Risk Model Evaluation
Topic 9 – Credit Risk Management
Topic10 – Liquidity Risk
===================
The content is difficult, but it is very practical and useful if you want to be a risk manager.

The tutorial, which is taught by TA Lupe, is mainly on how to use R to create the model learned in the lectures.

Note for OM students: Although the pre-requisites of this course is ISOM 3540, this course is actually (as the professor said) an advanced course to RMBI 3110. Some contents covered in RMBI 3110 will be used in this course, but the professor will talk about them again in the first two lectures, so don't worry.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is clear and the professor do not have a significant accent. She will illustrate some difficult ideas and explain what the symbols in the formula means.
She is also nice so feel free to ask her questions if there are any difficulties.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework (30%)
- Work in groups of 3.
- 3 assignments.
* Only very few marks (0.1~0.5/10) will be deducted if you make minor mistakes in the HW, so the mean is very high.

Midterm (30%)
- Open-book exam: you can use your laptop to view notes, but you cannot connect to the Internet.
- Calculator, Excel, R allowed.
- R coding not tested.
- Covers topics 1 - 5a
* The midterm this year is VERY similar to the sample paper (many of the questions are the same just with the values changed), so the mean is very high (89.9%).

Final Exam (40%)
- Rules same as the mid-term.
- Non-cumulative, covers topics 5b - 10.
* It is more difficult than the midterm. (Mean: 65.31, SD: 18.12)

The final grades are not released yet.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not many workload considering it is a 4-credit course.
The workload is actually smaller than many 3-credit courses.
